texts.definition: A Card Hand consists of the cards, which are owned by the player, but which have not yet been put into play.
examples: in "Poker" each of the players is dealt five cards, which define the [Card Hand](card-hands) for each player.
"Bohnanza" is a card game where the order of the cards in the [Card Hand](card-hands) is important, as the players have to play the cards in a specific sequence.
usage: The basic design question when using [Card Hands](card-hands) is determining the size of the hand; should all cards be distributed at the beginning of the game or should some cards be left in, for example, a [Drawing Stack](drawing-stacks).

Another fundamental design question regarding [Card Hands](card-hands) is how the size and content of the hands change. Having an initial set of cards that shrinks as cards are played makes use of [Limited Resources](limited-resources) and allows the game designer to limit the length of the game. Refilling the hand continuously as cards are being played creates a [Closed Economy](closed-economies) and frees the game design to determine the game length by other means.
Although most often consisting of [Cards,](cards) a [Card Hand](card-hands) can also consist of [Tiles](tiles) in games that have [Tile-Laying](tile-laying).
consequences: [Card Hands](card-hands) are [Containers](container) of [Cards](cards) that assign players [Ownership](ownership) to the [Cards.](cards) Typically [Card Hands](card-hands) are secret to all other players and being able to deduce the other players' hands offers a strategic advantage (i. e. a [Gain Information](gain-information) goal). However, the other players may know how many cards are in the [Card Hand](card-hands) and the cards might be marked, so the players have [Asymmetric Information](asymmetric-information) about the [Card Hands](card-hands) in play.
